Overview of IDL
Overview of IDL

Data Structures • A variable in IDL has both a structure and a data type associated with it. Both of these are dynamic, i.e. they can be changed via an assignment statement at any time. • Data types
Data Structures

Integer (16 bit, signed)

Assignment Statements
Assignment Statements

A = B + 1
A = B + 1

• A has the same structure as B, with a data type equal to that of the
• A has the same structure as B, with a data type equal to that of the • A

most precise operand in the expression on the right hand side. In this case it could be any type except string. If B is a vector or array then 1 is added to each element. A = 0 A = A * 0.5 B = A(*,3) A(*,3) = 0
most precise operand in the expression on the right hand side. In this
case it could be any type except string.
If B is a vector or array then 1 is added to each element.
A = 0
A = A * 0.5
B = A(*,3)
A(*,3) = 0

; A is a 16 bit integer ; A is now a 32 bit float ; B is equal to the 4th row of A ; Set all elements in 4th row of A equal to 0
; A is a 16 bit integer
; A is now a 32 bit float
; B is equal to the 4th row of A
; Set all elements in 4th row of A equal to 0

• Examples:
• Examples: • E x a m p l e s :

Syntax
Syntax

image = fltarr(512, 512) b = image(0:127, 0:127) image(*,100) = findgen(512) plot, image(*,120) ; Display the power spectrum as an image tvscl, alog(abs(fft(image, 1)))
image = fltarr(512, 512)
b = image(0:127, 0:127)
image(*,100) = findgen(512)
plot, image(*,120)
; Display the power spectrum as an image
tvscl, alog(abs(fft(image, 1)))

; zero filled array ; b is 128x128 array ; replace row 100 ; plot row 121
; zero filled array
; b is 128x128 array
; replace row 100
; plot row 121

ezca and EzcaScan
ezca and EzcaScan

EPICS extensions for “Easy Channel Access”
EPICS extensions for “Easy Channel Access”

- Don’t need to handle chids, just use PV name strings – hash table - Synchronous APIs - applications don’t have to handle callbacks
- Don’t need to handle chids, just use PV name strings – hash table
- Synchronous APIs - applications don’t have to handle callbacks

Ezca (partial list)
Ezca (partial list)

epicsShareFunc int epicsShareAPI ezcaGet(char *pvname, char ezcatype,

short *precision);

char *units); /* units must be at least EZCA_UNITS_SIZE large */

ezca and IDL

IDL can call “shareable libraries”, e.g. .so files on Unix, .dll files on Windows
IDL can call “shareable libraries”, e.g. .so files on Unix, .dll files
on Windows

• The argument passing convention is fixed, it is not compatible

IDL Channel Access API
IDL Channel Access API

Routines which return information about process variables
Routines which return information about process variables

Status = caGet(pvname, value, /string, maximum=max) Status = caGetControlLimits(pvname, low, high) Status = caGetGraphicLimits(pvname, low, high) Status = caGetPrecision(pvname, precision) Status = caGetStatus(pvname, timestamp, status, severity) Status = caGetUnits(pvname, units) Status = caGetEnumStrings(pvname, strings) Status = caGetCountAndType(pvname, count, type)
Status = caGet(pvname, value, /string, maximum=max)
Status = caGetControlLimits(pvname, low, high)
Status = caGetGraphicLimits(pvname, low, high)
Status = caGetPrecision(pvname, precision)
Status = caGetStatus(pvname, timestamp, status, severity)
Status = caGetUnits(pvname, units)
Status = caGetEnumStrings(pvname, strings)
Status = caGetCountAndType(pvname, count, type)

Routines which write new values to process variables Status = caPut(pvname, value, wait=wait)
Routines which write new values to process variables
Status = caPut(pvname, value, wait=wait)

Routines which control channel access timeouts
Routines which control channel access timeouts

Timeout = caGetTimeout() caSetTimeout, timeout RetryCount = caGetRetryCount() caSetRetryCount, retrycount
Timeout = caGetTimeout()
caSetTimeout, timeout
RetryCount = caGetRetryCount()
caSetRetryCount, retrycount

Routines which control synchronous groups
Routines which control synchronous groups

caStartGroup
stat = caEndGroup(status)

Routines which control channel access monitors
Routines which control channel access monitors

Status = caSetMonitor(pvname) Status = caClearMonitor(pvname) State = caCheckMonitor(pvname)
Status = caSetMonitor(pvname)
Status = caClearMonitor(pvname)
State = caCheckMonitor(pvname)

Routines which control debugging and error messages
Routines which control debugging and error messages

caDebug, state caTrace, state caError, err_string, /ON, /OFF, /PRINT, prefix=prefix
caDebug, state
caTrace, state
caError, err_string, /ON, /OFF, /PRINT, prefix=prefix

IDL EPICS Examples
IDL EPICS Examples

IDL> status = caget('13LAB:m1.VAL', position) IDL> help, status, position STATUS LONG = 0 POSITION DOUBLE = 517.19305 IDL> status = caget('13LAB:quadEM:mca1', spectrum) IDL> plot, spectrum IDL> help, status, spectrum STATUS LONG = 0 SPECTRUM LONG = Array[2048] IDL> plot, spectrum[0:500] IDL> fft_data = alog(abs(fft(spectrum,1))) IDL> plot, fft_data, xrange=[0,1023]
IDL> status = caget('13LAB:m1.VAL', position)
IDL> help, status, position
STATUS LONG = 0
POSITION DOUBLE = 517.19305
IDL> status = caget('13LAB:quadEM:mca1', spectrum)
IDL> plot, spectrum
IDL> help, status, spectrum
STATUS LONG = 0
SPECTRUM LONG = Array[2048]
IDL> plot, spectrum[0:500]
IDL> fft_data = alog(abs(fft(spectrum,1)))
IDL> plot, fft_data, xrange=[0,1023]

IDL EPICS Examples
IDL EPICS Examples

Move a motor DL> status = caput('13LAB:m8.VAL', 10000) IDL> status = caget('13LAB:m8.RBV', pos) IDL> print, pos
Move a motor
DL> status = caput('13LAB:m8.VAL', 10000)
IDL> status = caget('13LAB:m8.RBV', pos)
IDL> print, pos

IDL> status = caget('13LAB:m8.RBV', pos) IDL> print, pos
IDL> status = caget('13LAB:m8.RBV', pos)
IDL> print, pos

IDL> status = caget('13LAB:m8.RBV', pos) IDL> print, pos
IDL> status = caget('13LAB:m8.RBV', pos)
IDL> print, pos

Ezca timeout values are important! IDL> print, cagettimeout()
Ezca timeout values are important!
IDL> print, cagettimeout()

IDL> t0=systime(1)&for i=1,100 do t=caget('13LAB:m1', v)&print, systime(1)-t0
IDL> t0=systime(1)&for i=1,100 do t=caget('13LAB:m1', v)&print, systime(1)-t0

2.9898720 IDL> casettimeout, .001 IDL> t0=systime(1)&for i=1,100 do t=caget('13LAB:m1', v)&print, systime(1)-t0
2.9898720
IDL> casettimeout, .001
IDL> t0=systime(1)&for i=1,100 do t=caget('13LAB:m1', v)&print, systime(1)-t0

IDL EPICS Examples
IDL EPICS Examples

Using monitors
Using monitors

Monitored channels read the cached values on caget() Can check whether a monitor has happened (a Channel Access value callback)
Monitored channels read the cached values on caget()
Can check whether a monitor has happened (a Channel Access value callback)

IDL> status = caSetMonitor('13LAB:m8.DMOV') IDL> state = caCheckMonitor('13LAB:m8.DMOV') IDL> help, state STATE LONG = 1 IDL> status = caget('13LAB:m8.DMOV', done) IDL> help, done DONE INT = 1 IDL> state = caCheckMonitor('13LAB:m8.DMOV') IDL> help, state STATE LONG = 0 IDL> status = caput('13LAB:m8.VAL', 0) IDL> state = caCheckMonitor('13LAB:m8.DMOV') IDL> help, state STATE LONG = 1 IDL> status = caget('13LAB:m8.DMOV', done) IDL> help, state STATE LONG = 1 IDL> help, done DONE INT = 0 Monitors are useful for seeing that a PV changed state, even if its value is the
IDL> status = caSetMonitor('13LAB:m8.DMOV')
IDL> state = caCheckMonitor('13LAB:m8.DMOV')
IDL> help, state
STATE LONG = 1
IDL> status = caget('13LAB:m8.DMOV', done)
IDL> help, done
DONE INT = 1
IDL> state = caCheckMonitor('13LAB:m8.DMOV')
IDL> help, state
STATE LONG = 0
IDL> status = caput('13LAB:m8.VAL', 0)
IDL> state = caCheckMonitor('13LAB:m8.DMOV')
IDL> help, state
STATE LONG = 1
IDL> status = caget('13LAB:m8.DMOV', done)
IDL> help, state
STATE LONG = 1
IDL> help, done
DONE INT = 0
Monitors are useful for seeing that a PV changed state, even if its value is the

same because one “missed” the transition. For example, PV goes 0->1->0. IDL polling might miss the one state, but checking a monitor would let one know that it happened.
same because one “missed” the transition. For example, PV goes 0->1->0. IDL
polling might miss the one state, but checking a monitor would let one know
that it happened.

IDL EPICS Class Libraries
IDL EPICS Class Libraries

IDL object classes that hide the underlying EPICS process variables IDL objects treat all data as private, only accessible through methods.
IDL object classes that hide the underlying EPICS process
variables
IDL objects treat all data as private, only accessible through
methods.

• Provide an object-oriented interface to common beamline
• Provide an object-oriented interface to common beamline • P r o v i d e
a n
o b j e c t - o r i e n t e d
i n t e r f a c e
t o
c o m m o n
b e a m l i n e

objects (motors, scalers, mcas, scans) - epics_motor - epics_scaler - epics_mca (inherits device-independent mca class) - epics_med (multi-element detector) - epics_sscan
objects (motors, scalers, mcas, scans)
- epics_motor
- epics_scaler
- epics_mca (inherits device-independent mca class)
- epics_med (multi-element detector)
- epics_sscan

• Example of epics_motor
• Example of epics_motor • E x a m p l e
o f
e p i c s _ m o t o r

IDL> motor = obj_new('EPICS_MOTOR', '13LAB:m8') IDL> motor->move, 1000. ; Move to absolute position 10. IDL> motor->wait ; Wait for it to get there
IDL> motor = obj_new('EPICS_MOTOR', '13LAB:m8')
IDL> motor->move, 1000. ; Move to absolute position 10.
IDL> motor->wait ; Wait for it to get there

IDL EPICS Class Libraries
IDL EPICS Class Libraries

• Example of epics_mca
• Example of epics_mca • E x a m p l e
o f
e p i c s _ m c a

IDL> mca = obj_new('epics_mca', '13LAB:aim_adc1') IDL> mca->erase IDL> mca->acquire_on IDL> data = mca->get_data() IDL> plot, data
IDL> mca = obj_new('epics_mca', '13LAB:aim_adc1')
IDL> mca->erase
IDL> mca->acquire_on
IDL> data = mca->get_data()
IDL> plot, data

• Example of epics_scaler
• Example of epics_scaler • E x a m p l e
o f
e p i c s _ s c a l e r

IDL> scaler = obj_new('epics_scaler', '13LAB:scaler1') IDL> scaler->start, 10. ; Count for 10 seconds IDL> scaler->wait ; Wait for it to get done IDL> counts = scaler->read(); Read the counts on each channel IDL> print, counts
IDL> scaler = obj_new('epics_scaler', '13LAB:scaler1')
IDL> scaler->start, 10. ; Count for 10 seconds
IDL> scaler->wait ; Wait for it to get done
IDL> counts = scaler->read(); Read the counts on each channel
IDL> print, counts

IDL EPICS Class Libraries
IDL EPICS Class Libraries

• epics_sscan • Designed to do the following:
• epics_sscan • e p i c s _ s s c a n
• Designed to do the following: • D e s i g n e d
t o
d o
t h e
f o l l o w i n g :

- Provide an object-oriented interface to standard EPICS scans, enabling user written software to easily access scan header information and data.
- Provide an object-oriented interface to standard EPICS scans,
enabling user written software to easily access scan header
information and data.

- Provide an easy way to read MDA files written by the saveData
- Provide an easy way to read MDA files written by the saveData

function in synApps.
function in synApps.

- Provide an easy way to get scan data into the IDL iTools system. iTools provide powerful interfaces for visualizing data, zooming in, adding annotation, and producing publication quality plots. - Provide a way to convert binary scan files (e.g. MDA) into ASCII - Does not currently communicate with the IOC for real-time data,
- Provide an easy way to get scan data into the IDL iTools system.
iTools provide powerful interfaces for visualizing data, zooming
in, adding annotation, and producing publication quality plots.
- Provide a way to convert binary scan files (e.g. MDA) into ASCII
- Does not currently communicate with the IOC for real-time data,

but this is planned for the future
but this is planned for the future

This function returns the data from the MCA.
This function returns the data from the MCA.

EPICS_MCA::GET_DATA
EPICS_MCA::GET_DATA

[Previous Routine] [Next Routine] [List of Routines]
[Previous Routine] [Next Routine] [List of Routines]

EPICS_MCA::GET_DATA
EPICS_MCA::GET_DATA

NAME:
NAME:

PURPOSE:
PURPOSE:

CATEGORY:
CATEGORY:

EPICS device class library.
EPICS device class library.

CALLING SEQUENCE:
CALLING SEQUENCE:

Result = epics_mca->GET_DATA()
Result = epics_mca->GET_DATA()

KEYWORD_PARAMETERS:
KEYWORD_PARAMETERS:

CHECK_NEW:
CHECK_NEW:

OPTIONAL OUTPUTS:
OPTIONAL OUTPUTS:

NEW_FLAG:
NEW_FLAG:

A flag which indicates that this routine should only return the data if it has changed.
A flag which indicates that this routine should only return
the data if it has changed.

If CHECK_FLAG is set, then NEW_FLAG will be 1 if the function is returning new data, 0 if the function is not returning new data. If CHECK_FLAG is set and NEW_FLAG is 0 then the function returns -1.
If CHECK_FLAG is set, then NEW_FLAG will be 1 if the function
is returning new data, 0 if the function is not returning new
data. If CHECK_FLAG is set and NEW_FLAG is 0 then the function
returns -1.

PROCEDURE:
PROCEDURE:

This function reads the data from the hardware using the EPICS MCA record, and then invokes MCA::GET_DATA
This function reads the data from the hardware using the EPICS MCA
record, and then invokes MCA::GET_DATA

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:

See MCA::GET_DATA().
See MCA::GET_DATA(). S e e
M C A : : G E T _ D A T A ( ) .

MODIFICATION HISTORY:
MODIFICATION HISTORY:

Written by: Mark Rivers, October 1, 1997 Nov. 14, 1997 Mark Rivers. Changed routine to eliminate setting rec.READ back to 0, since record support does this automatically and it was causing record to process again.
Written by: Mark Rivers, October 1, 1997
Nov. 14, 1997 Mark Rivers. Changed routine to eliminate setting
rec.READ back to 0, since record support does this
automatically and it was causing record to process
again.

19-Sep-1998 MLR Added /WAIT to caput, since default is not to wait
19-Sep-1998 MLR Added /WAIT to caput, since default is not to wait

for callback now.
for callback now.

17-Mar-1999 MLR Removed /WAIT from caput, to be compatible with
17-Mar-1999 MLR Removed /WAIT from caput, to be compatible with

version 4.3 and later of the MCA record, which does not fire forward links until acquisition is complete.
version 4.3 and later of the MCA record, which does
not fire forward links until acquisition is complete.

28-Mar-1999 MLR Changed routine so it no longer pokes READ field.
28-Mar-1999 MLR Changed routine so it no longer pokes READ field.

This assumes that someone else (typically a database) is periodically poking the READ field. The object initialization code now sets a monitor on the VAL field. Added New_flag output and CHECK_NEW keyword.
This assumes that someone else (typically a database)
is periodically poking the READ field. The object
initialization code now sets a monitor on the VAL
field. Added New_flag output and CHECK_NEW keyword.

epicsPV: Subclasses Geoff Savage's CaChannel class
epicsPV: Subclasses Geoff Savage's CaChannel class e p i c s P V :
S u b c l a s s e s G e o f f S a v a g e ' s
C a C h a n n e l
c l a s s

If a PV name is given then the class constructor will do a searchw() by default.
If a PV name is given then the class constructor will do a
searchw() by default.

• setMonitor() sets a generic callback routine for value change events. Subsequent getw(), getValue() or array_get() calls will return the value from the most recent callback, and hence do not result in any network activity or latency. This can greatly improve performance.
• setMonitor() sets a generic callback routine for value change • s e t M o n i t o r ( ) s e t s a g e n e r i c c a l l b a c k r o u t i n e
f o r
v a l u e
c h a n g e
events. Subsequent getw(), getValue() or array_get() calls will
return the value from the most recent callback, and hence do
not result in any network activity or
latency. This can greatly improve performance.

• checkMonitor() returns a flag to indicate if a callback has occurred since the last call to checkMonitor(), getw(), getValue() or array_get(). It can be used to increase efficiency in polling applications.
• checkMonitor() returns a flag to indicate if a callback has • c h e c k M o n i t o r ( )
r e t u r n s
a

i f

h a s
occurred since the last call to checkMonitor(), getw(),
getValue() or array_get(). It can be used to increase efficiency
in polling applications.

information from an EPICS PV without having to use callbacks. In addition to the PV value, this will return the graphic, control and alarm limits, etc.
information from an EPICS PV without having to use
callbacks. In addition to the PV value, this will return
the graphic, control and alarm limits, etc.

• putWait() calls array_put_callback() and waits for the callback to occur before it returns. This allows programs to use array_put_callback() synchronously and without user-written callbacks.
• putWait() calls array_put_callback() and waits for the • p u t W a i t ( ) c a l l s a r r a y _ p u t _ c a l l b a c k ( ) a n d w a i t s f o r t h e
callback to occur before it returns. This allows

from epicsMotor import * m = epicsMotor(’13LAB:m5’) m.move(10.) m.wait() m.get_position(dial=1, readback=1) 9.9609375

• Methods: • M e t h o d s :

- start(), stop(), read(), wait(), get_label(), set_label()

• Example use:
• Example use: • E x a m p l e
u s e :

>>> from epicsScaler import * >>> s = epicsScaler('13LAB:scaler1') >>> s.get_counts() >>> s.read() [0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0] >>> s.start(1.) >>> s.wait() >>> s.read() [10000000, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0]
>>> from epicsScaler import *
>>> s = epicsScaler('13LAB:scaler1')
>>> s.get_counts()
>>> s.read()
[0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0]
>>> s.start(1.)
>>> s.wait()
>>> s.read()
[10000000, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0]
